ANGLO-FRENCH FINANCIAL, ARRANGEMENTS0 Memorandum by the Chancellor of the Exchegue I visited Paris on Monday in order to reach agreement with Monsieur Paul Reynaud on a number of points so as to put into practical effect the -principle of monetary and financial solidarity which had already been accepted. The most important point on our side was to obtain an under talcing that the French would not ash to have gold for the sterling which they now hold (some £20 millions) or for further amounts of sterling which they may acquire during the whole of the war, and that the French would supply us, in return for sterling, with all the francs v/hich we may need for the British Expeditionary Force and for purchases in the French Empire. On this and on a number of other points full agreement was reached and it would have been possible to sign the Agreement on Monday night but for one question which remained outstanding. The French proposed that the two Governments should share certain items of expenditure for the common cause, namely:( l) future financial assistance to neutral and allied countries; (2) losses on blockade purchases; (3) the expenses of the Polish armed forces, and Czechoslovak armed forces (if and when raised)o U) expenditure under the following clause "If the development of tho war in third countries invloves extraordinary expenses in the common cause which would fall to an unreasonable degree upon one of the two Governments, then this principle /of sharing expenses/7 shall be applicable so far as agreed bet ween the two Governments"
The French p r 0 p O S e c L that (unless otherwise agreed) our contribution to such items of common expenditure should be twice as much as theirs. After full consideration I felt that it would be right for me to accept these proposals, provided that, instead of us contributing twice as much as the French, we should contribute 60;'o and the French 40?o. The amount of money involved in the difference between the French proposal and mine is not very larger For each £100 of expenditure shared, our contribution will be about £67 according to the French proposal and will be £60 according to mine* It is not possible to estimate the amount involved except as regards the cost of the Polish armed forces0 Three Polish destroyers, three Polish submarines and a depot ship are at present serving with the British Navy, and four bomber squadrons with our Air Force, while four fighter squadrons are serving with the French Air Force and a military force is being raised in France- The total cost may amount to something like £50 millions in the first year of war. The cost which falls on us under present arrangements is perhaps £10 millions in the first year of war, which would be increased to £27 millions under Mo Reynaudfs proposal and to £24 millions under mine. But although the difference between us is not much in terms of amount, I felt that on psychological and political grounds it would be very undesirable for us to accept an arrangement by which our contribution to items of common expenditure will be double that of the French contribution. We are certainly a wealthier nation than France, but I do not think that it would be true to say that we are twice as
wealthy.. If we agreed to contribute twice as much as the pjpench, there is a danger that sooner or later some critics will say that the French are as usual being avaricious and we are as usual being duped. Other critics (encouraged by German propaganda) will say that we are supplying the money and the French the men. I do not think that it would be in the interest of either Government that criticism of this kind should arise. I feel that a contribution of 60?o by us and 40% by France is much less likely to give rise to such criticism than a contribution by us twice as large as the contribution of France. I did my best to persuade M, Reynaud to accept my proposal, but he said that his own proposal had been approved by the French Cahi.net and that he had spoken to M. Daladier and he could not agree to alter it. I said that in these circumstances we could only initial the Agreement subject to the settlement of this one point and that I must report the position to my colleagues. I think that we should stick to our proposal, for I believe it to be right for the reasons given above. If the War Cabinet approve, I will so inform M. Reynaud, and if the French still adhere to their own view I shall have to report the matter to the War Cabinet again. I am circulating for the information of the War Cabinet the text as initialled and a summary which was prepared for communication to the Press if the Agreement had been signed( initialled) J . S . *ury Chambers, S . W. I n , 5th December 1Q30
DRAFT SU1ILARY (for the Press) . The two Governments have agreed that it is in the interest of Tooth countries to avoid alterations in the existing official rate of exchange between the pound and the franc. The francs required by the United Kingdom (including those for the B o E , P . ) will be provided against payment in sterling and the sterling required by Prance (including that required for the purchase of raw materials in the British Empire) will be provided against francs. Both countries will for the duration of the war be in a position to cover the whole of their requirements in the currency of the other country by payment in their own currency without any question of their having to find gold. The sterling held by the French monetary authorities will be available for expenditure in the whole of the sterling area and the francs held by the United Kingdom monetary authorities will be available for expenditure in all the French empire. The question of sharing equitably the expenses which the two Governments have to defray in gold and dollars will be kept under review. The United Kingdom and French Treasuries will have meetings at intervals of not less than 3 months to review the position of the Allied Governments as regards their resources in gold and foreign exchange. Neither Government will raise a foreign loan or credit except in agreement with (or jointly with) the other Governmento
Neither Government will impose fresh restrictions on t h e imports from the other country during the war for p r o t e c t i v e purposes or for exchange reasons. The two Governments will maintain contact as regards t h e i r policy in regard to prices. Finally, the two Governments will share certain i t e m s of expenditure in the common cause such as financial a s s i s t a n c e to other countries and the cost of the armed f o r c e s of their Polish ally. The contribution of the two Governments will be fixed on a basis which will take due a c c o u n t of the national wealth of each. In general, t h e French contribution will be 40/J, and the United Kingdom contribution 60,h of the total. These arrangements will remain in force till 6 months after the signature of the Treaty of Peace. This is my proposal; M. Reynard wants 33fj to 66?d or 35;j to 65;o,

Draft Anglo ^rench^ ^inanci^, Aj;reemeat. as initialled on 4th December, 1939; with exchange of letters^ The undersigned, duly authorised by their respective Governments, have agreed as follows:-- Article l n The Government of the French Republic and the Government of the United Kingdom consider that it is in the common interest to avoid alterations in the official rate of exchange between the franc and the pound sterling. No such-change will be made without prior agreement "between the two Governments0 Article 2, Each Exchange Equalisation Fund will continue to be solely responsible as regards the quotation for its currency in markets of third countries0 But the monetary authorities of the two countries will consult together on the policy to he followed in regard to this question and on any intervention which may seem necessary0 Article 50 The United Kingdom Equalisation Fund and the French Stabilisation Fund will continue to soil sterling for francs and francs for sterling at the official rates0 If the United Kingdom Fund requires francs (whether for governmental expenditure, such a expenditure of the British Expeditionary Force in France, or otherwise), such francs will he sold "by the French Fund against pounds sterling at the official rate,, (If the French Fund requires pounds sterling for any purpose, those pounds will be sold by the United Kingdom Fund against francs at the official rate.)
No limit will be fixed to the amounts of sterling or francs to be purchased in accordance with the preceding Article. If the French Fund should at any time hold sterling in excess of £50 millions, the excess shall be used to purchase British Treasury Bills expressed as payable in francs at a franc-sterling rate calculated in accordance with the following Article. These Bills shall bear interest at 3% and shall be repayable one year after the conclusion of the war,, They will be renewable at the option of either Government for two further periods of one year eacho Similar arrangements will apply as regards the investment of amounts in francs held by the United Kingdom Fund in excess of 9 milliard francs. There will be delivered to the United Kingdom Fund Treasury Bills expressed as payable in pounds sterling at a fixed sterlingfranc rate. Such Treasury Bills shall be purchased by the United Kingdom Treasury or by the French Treasury at any time if the total amount of the pounds sterling or francs held by either Fund falls below £50 millions or 9 milliard francs. The pounds sterling and the francs held by the two Funds up to the limit of £50 millions and 9 milliard francs shall be invested by either Central Bank in agreement with and through the other Central Bank. Article 5. Neither Government will ask for a gold security nor for any specific security for the currency obtained by the two Exchange Equalisation Funds as laid down above. Nor will any request be made for the conversion of these -Ikcurrencies into g o l do If the two Governments should agree to change the official rate of exchange between the franc and the pound, the amount of francs-to be paid by the United Kingdom Fund would be calculated at the rate in force when the sterling was acquired. A similar arrangement would apply to francs held by the United Kingdom Fund. The rate of exchange between francs and pounds sterling as regards the Treasury Bills referred to in the preceding Article will be calculated in the same way-o Article 6c The pounds sterling held by the French Fund may be used to pay for all expenditure in "pounds sterling in the sterling area, that is to say, in the British Empire (excluding Canada, Newfoundland and Hongkong), Egypt, the Sudan and Iraq. The francs held by the United Kingdom Fund may be used to pay for all expenditure in francs on French territory and in the French Empire. Payments in other countries in pounds sterling or in francs will be made after agreement between the two Governments, it being understood that the possibilities of utilising pounds sterling or francs by these countries will be equitably shared. Article 7 r The Exchange Equalisation Funds will, if necessary, provide against pounds sterling or against francs, the local currencies needed by the other Fund for all payments in the sterling area or in the French Empire0
The two Treasuries will consider and constantly watch over all questions relating to the equitable distribution of expenditure in dollars or in gold borne by each allied country, which are made necessary by the conduct of the ware Article 9 0 The two Treasuries will examine from time to time, and at least once every three months, the amount of and the reasons for movements in gold or foreign exchange, and will propose the measures of all kinds required to maintain the conditions of a lasting monetary equilibriurno Article- 100 If the raw materials and goods required for the prosecution of the war existing in the sterling area and in the French Empire cannot for practical reasons be shared proportionately to the respective needs of the two countries, an adjustment in gold or in exchange shall be made by the country which receives less than its due share of the raw materials or goods drawn from the sterling area or the French Empire. Article 11c As regards their relations with their countries, the two Governments will keep each other informed, co-operate and agree before taking any steps in relation to financial or monetary questions which might affect the interests of the other country directly or indirectly* Article 12 o In particular, the two Governments will consult together as laid down by the preceding Article ( l) with the object of settling the currency in which imports from their countries will be paid for. Payments should be made as far as possible in francs or in pounds -16sterling or in the money of the exporting country. The two Governments will if necessary assist each other in negotiating payments agreements with third countries. (2)in order to obtain, where possible in third countries agreements for paying for imports partly by means of blocked currencies.-. Article 13o The tv/o Governments will consult together as laid down in Article 11 before taking steps for the mobilisation on the market of a third country of all or part of their holdings of foreign securities. Neither Government will sell securities payable in the currency of the other country without having obtained the prior agreement of the other Government0 Article 14. No loan will be raised on a foreign market by either Government without a prior agreement between the two Governments. They will seek to obtain joint loans. Article 15. The two Governments will not impose fresh restrictions on trade between their two countries for the purpose of protecting home industry or for foreign exchange reasons . They will do all that is possible to establish the same solidarity between their Empires. Article 16. The two Governments will consult together on all questions relating to price policy in order to avoid measures tending to weaken the monetary solidarity established by the present Agreements Any difficulties which may arise in regard to this matter will be examined by the two Treasuries*
m The two Governments agree to share any loans which they may hereafter grant in common to mutual or allied countries in the proportion of for France and for the United Kingdom. If the development of the war in third countries involvde extraordinary expenses in the common cause which would fall to an unreasonable degree upon one of the two Governments, t.\.en this basis of distribution will be applicable to these expenses ao fnr a agreed between the two s Governments. Article 18. The two Governments will contribute on the basis laid down in the preceding Article to the payment of the expenses of the Polish and Czechoslovak armed forces fighting in the common cause. Article 19. Losses resulting from blo.ckade purchases will be shared on the basis laid down in Article 17. Purchases made by either Government in accordance with a common decision in a neutral country at prices considerably above world prices will he treated as blockade purchases. Article 30. The present Agreement shall remain in force for the whole duration of the war and for a period of six months after the signature of the Treaty of Peace. Done in duplicate in French and In English, both texts being authentic.
